book_summary.overall_summary:
Venture Deals is a practical, experience-driven guide that demystifies venture capital term sheets and the financing process for entrepreneurs and new investors. The book opens by mapping the venture ecosystem—who the players are (entrepreneurs, angels, VCs, lawyers, mentors) and how their incentives, time horizons, and constraints shape negotiations. Using historical anecdotes and candid forewords, the authors emphasize that the term sheet is the pivotal negotiating document and reduce its complexity to two core levers: economics (who owns what) and control (who makes the big decisions). From that foundation, the book walks readers clause-by-clause through modern term sheets and explains why particular provisions exist, who asks for them, and how they translate into ownership and governance outcomes.

The middle sections turn the conceptual into the concrete. The authors explain cap-table math with worked examples, show how option pools and post-money vs pre-money mechanics affect dilution, and describe convertible-debt instruments (notes, SAFEs/KISS) and their traps. Interleaved entrepreneur-perspective sidebars provide negotiation strategies: when to fight, when to accept boilerplate, how to handle no-shop clauses, information rights, registration rights, ROFRs, PIIAs, founder activity clauses, indemnification, and assignment. Practical attention is paid to drafting, timing, and the role of counsel—urging founders to understand the math and not blindly trust lawyers.

Later chapters focus on legal hygiene and broader context: the irreversible legal mistakes (83(b) elections, employment/IP documentation) that can destroy value, and the macro view of entrepreneurial ecosystems (the Boulder Thesis) that explains why some places produce sustained startup activity. Throughout, the tone is balanced—sympathetic to founders yet realistic about investor protections—and the book emphasizes transparency, disciplined governance, and relationship-based negotiation. Taken together, Venture Deals mixes legal, financial, strategic, and cultural lessons to make readers able negotiators and better stewards of their companies.

Chapter 1, “The Players,” introduces the human and institutional participants who drive venture financings and builds directly on the Introduction’s framing of the term sheet as an exercise in balancing economics and control. Where the Introduction explained the structure and purpose of a term sheet, this chapter explains who sits across the table and why each player’s incentives, time horizons, and constraints matter to the deal. It profiles entrepreneurs (their goals, equity sensitivities, and operational priorities), venture capitalists (their fund structure, return targets, and selection criteria), and other critical actors—angel investors, syndicates, lawyers, and mentors—highlighting how each influences negotiation dynamics and eventual deal terms.

By naming financing-stage terminology (seed, Series A, etc.) and distinguishing types of VC firms (early-stage, growth, corporate, strategic), the chapter gives practical vocabulary that feeds into later chapters on pricing, liquidation preferences, board composition, and protective provisions. It also lays out how syndication works (lead vs. follow investors), the role angels play before institutional rounds, and why lawyers and mentors are more than service providers: they shape diligence, documentation, and founder behavior. Understanding these players clarifies why specific term-sheet provisions emerge, who pushes for them, and how entrepreneurs can strategically choose partners and structure rounds—setting the stage for the detailed economic and control-term discussions in subsequent chapters.

Foreword

remember the first week of my career as a VC. I was 25 years
old, it was 1986, and I had just landed a summer job in a venture
capital firm. I was working for three experienced venture capitalists
in a small firm called Euclid Partners, where I ended up spending
the first 10 years of my VC career. One of those three partners,
Bliss McCrum, peeked his head into my office (I had an office in
Rockefeller Center at age 25) and said to me, "Can you model out
a financing for XYZ Company at a $9 million pre-money, raising
$3 million, with an unissued option pool of 10%?" and then went
back to the big office in the rear he shared with the other founding
partner, Milton Pappas.

I sat at my desk and started thinking about the request. I
understood the "raising $3 million" bit. I thought I could figure
out the "unissued option pool of 10%" bit. But what the hell was
"pre-money"? I had never heard that term. This was almost a decade
before Netscape and Internet search so searching online for it wasn't
an option. After spending ten minutes getting up the courage, I
walked back to that big office, peeked my head in, and said to Bliss,
"Can you explain pre-money to me?"

Thus began my 31-year education in venture capital that is still
going on as I write this.

The venture capital business was a cottage industry back in 1985,
with club deals and a language all of its own. A cynic would say it was
designed this way to be opaque to everyone other than the VCs so that
they would have all the leverage in negotiations with entrepreneurs.
I don't entirely buy that narrative. I think the VC business grew up in
a few small offices in Boston, New York, and San Francisco, and the
dozens-maybe as many as a hundred-of main participants, along

with their lawyers, came up with structures that made sense to them.
They then developed a shorthand so that they could communicate
among themselves.

But whatever the origin story was, the language of venture deals
is foreign to many and remains opaque and confusing to this day.
This works to the advantage of industry insiders and to the disadvan-
tage of those who are new to startups and venture capital.

In the early 2000s, after I wound down my first venture capital
firm, Flatiron Partners, and before we started USV, I started blogging.
One of my goals with my AVC blog (at www.avc.com) was to bring
transparency to this opaque world that I had been inhabiting for
almost 20 years. I was joined in this blogging thing by Brad Feld, a
friend and frequent coinvestor. Club investing has not gone away
and that's a good thing. By reading AVC and Feld Thoughts regu-
larly, an entrepreneur could get up to speed on startups and venture
capital. Brad and I received a tremendous amount of positive feed-
back on our efforts to bring transparency to the venture capital busi-
ness so we kept doing it, and now if you search for something like
"participating preferred" you will find posts written by both me and
Brad on that first search results page.

Brad and his partner Jason Mendelson (a recovering startup law-
yer turned VC) took things a step further and wrote a book called
Venture Deals back in 2011. It has turned into a classic and is now on
its Third Edition. If Venture Deals had been around in 1985, I would
not have had to admit to Bliss that I had no idea what pre-money
meant.

If there is a guidebook to navigating the mysterious and confusing
language of venture capital and venture capital financing structures,
it is Venture Deals. Anyone interested in startups, entrepreneurship,
and angel and venture capital financings should do themselves a
favor and read it.

Fred Wilson
USV Partner
July 2016

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
Introduction: The Art of the Term Sheet

0
ne of the first famous venture capital investments was Digital
Equipment Corporation (DEC). In 1957, American Research and
Development Corporation (AR&D), one of the first venture capital
firms, invested $70,000 in DEC. When DEC went public in 1968, this
investment was worth over $355 million, or a return of over 5,000
times the invested capital. AR&D's investment in DEC was one of the
original venture capital home runs.

In 1957, the venture capital industry was just being created. At the
time, the investor community in the United States was uninterested
in investing in computer companies, as the last wave of computer-
related startups had performed poorly and even large companies
were having difficulty making money in the computer business. We
can envision the frustration of DEC's cofounders, Ken Olson and
Harlan Anderson, as the investors they talked to rejected them
and their fledgling idea for a business. We can also imagine their
joy when Georges Doriot, the founder of American Research and
Development Corporation, offered to fund them. After a number
of conversations and meetings, Doriot sent Olson and Anderson a
letter expressing his interest in investing, along with his proposed
terms. Today, this document is called the term sheet.

Now, imagine what that term sheet looked like. There are three
different possibilities. The first is that it was a typed one-page let-
ter that said, "We would like to invest $70,000 in your company
and buy 78 percent of it." The next is that it was two pages of legal
terms that basically said, "We would like to invest $70,000 in your
company and buy 78 percent of it." Or it could have been an eight-
page typed document that had all kinds of protective provisions, vesting

<!-- PageNumber="1" -->
<!-- PageFooter="www.itdf.ir" -->
<!-- PageBreak -->

<!-- PageNumber="2" -->
<!-- PageHeader="Venture Deals" -->

arrangements, drag-along rights, and Securities and Exchange Com-
mission (SEC) registration rights.

Our guess is that it was not the third option. Over the past 50
years, the art of the term sheet has evolved and expanded, reaching
its current eight (or so) page literary masterpiece. These eight pages
contain a lot more than "We'd like to invest $X in your company
and get Y% of it," but, as you'll learn, there really are only two key
things that matter in the actual term sheet negotiation-economics
and control.

In DEC's case, by owning 78% of the company, AR&D effec-
tively had control of the company. And the price was clearly
defined-$70,000 bought 78% of the company, resulting in a $90,000
post-money valuation.

Today's venture capital investments have many more nuances.
Individual venture capitalists (VCs) usually end up owning less than
50 percent of the company, so they don't have effective voting con-
trol but often negotiate provisions that give them control over major
decisions by the company. Many companies end up with multiple
venture capitalists who invest in the company at different points in
time, resulting in different ownership percentages, varying rights,
and diverging motivations. Founders don't always stay with the com-
pany through the exit and, in some cases, they end up leaving rela-
tively early in the life of a company for a variety of reasons. Compa-
nies fail, so venture capitalists have gotten much more focused on
protecting themselves for the downside as well as participating in the
upside. Governance issues are always complex, especially when you
have a lot of people sitting around the negotiating table.

While it would be desirable to do venture capital deals with a
simple agreement on price, a handshake, and a short legal agree-
ment, this rarely happens. And while there have been plenty of
attempts to standardize the term sheet over the years, the prolifera-
tion of lawyers, venture capitalists, and entrepreneurs, along with a
steadily increasing number of investments, has prevented this from
happening. Ironically, the actual definitive documents have become
more standard over time. Whether it is the Internet age that has
spread information across the ecosystem or clients growing tired of
paying legal bills, there are more similarities in the documents today
than ever before. As a result, we can lend you our experience in how
venture financings are usually done. The good news is once you've

<!-- PageFooter="www.itdf.ir" -->
<!-- PageBreak -->

<!-- PageNumber="3" -->
<!-- PageHeader="Introduction: The Art of the Term Sheet" -->

negotiated the term sheet, you are done with the hard part. As a
result, that's where we are going to focus our energy in this book.

Throughout this book we will cover not only the what and the
how, but also the why things work as they do. Let's begin our explora-
tion of venture capital financings by discussing the various players
involved.

Using the DEC/AR&D anecdote to show how simple early investments once were, the authors trace how term sheets have expanded into multi-page documents packed with protective provisions. They emphasize that despite the proliferation of clauses and lawyers, only two things truly matter in negotiation: economics (who owns what) and control (who steers major decisions). The chapter sets the ground for the rest of the book by explaining that once a term sheet is agreed, the hardest negotiation is typically behind the entrepreneur.

Beyond the term sheet itself, the chapter thoroughly maps the ecosystem of people and institutions that participate in financings. It breaks down VC firm hierarchies (MDs/GPs, partners, principals, associates, analysts), describes different investor types (angels, super angels, micro‑VCs), explains syndicates and lead investors, and stresses the critical role of an experienced lawyer. It also covers practical fundraising elements—round nomenclature (Seed, Series A/B/C, round extensions like B‑1), executive summaries, demos, PPMs, and tactics like using multiple VCs to create competition. Throughout, the authors offer entrepreneur‑centric advice: do your homework on firms and people, prioritize demos and concise materials, manage timing to create leverage, and pick lawyers who know VC deals.

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
Overview of the Term Sheet

A
t the end of 2005, during the dark ages when venture capital was
very much out of favor, we participated in a financing that was much
more difficult than it needed to be. All of the participants were to
blame, and ignorance of what really mattered in the negotiation
kept things going much longer than was necessary. We talked about
what to do and, at the risk of giving away super-top-secret venture
capital magic tricks, decided to write a blog series on Brad's blog
(Feld Thoughts-www.feld.com) that deconstructed a venture capital
term sheet and explained each section.

That blog series was the inspiration for this book. The next few
chapters cover the most frequently discussed terms in a venture capi-
tal term sheet. Many venture capitalists (VCs) love to negotiate hard
on every term as though the health of their children depended on
them getting the terms just right. Sometimes this is inexperience on
the part of the VC; often, it's just a negotiating tactic.

The specific language that we refer to is from actual term sheets.
In addition to describing and explaining the specific terms, we give
you examples of what to focus on and implications from the perspec-
tives of the company, VCs, and entrepreneurs.

chapter_summaries.summary:
Chapter 6 shifts the book’s focus from describing term sheets and their clauses (Chapter 5) and the players who negotiate them (Chapter 1) to practical, entrepreneur‑centered negotiation tactics. The central, repeated piece of advice is procedural and protective: if a term sheet contains a no‑shop clause — i.e., a provision that prevents the company from soliciting other offers — insist that key employment and founder terms be spelled out before you sign. The chapter flags a VC’s unwillingness to commit to basic employment terms early as a major red flag, because a signed no‑shop can lock founders into a negotiation posture without clear protections on role, compensation, vesting, severance, and change‑of‑control treatment.

The chapter also underscores that term sheets are not absolute guarantees. Beyond the common economic and control provisions discussed earlier, there are many unusual or onerous conditions that can be tucked into a paragraph; if you can imagine it, someone has probably written it. Entrepreneurs are reminded to scrutinize every clause closely, to understand which provisions are binding or condition precedent, and to treat a signed term sheet — especially one with restrictive shop language and unspecified employment terms — as not the same as a closed deal.

chapter_summaries.summary:
Chapter 7, “The Entrepreneur's Perspective,” reframes the term sheet debate around a founder-first norm: embrace transparency with your investors rather than fear it. Building on the earlier chapters that identify the term sheet as the crossroads of economics and control, this chapter argues that robust information rights are a healthy governance tool for a modern startup and a practical requirement of outside capital. The author counsels entrepreneurs to adopt the discipline of sending regular budgets and financial statements to shareholders and to view disclosure as part of running a professional, accountable organization; if a founder is unwilling to make that commitment, they should seriously question taking outside investment. For founders who are naturally cautious, the chapter accepts adding a strict confidentiality clause to protect genuinely sensitive information, but treats that as a narrow exception rather than a reason to resist normal investor information rights.

This chapter connects doctrine to day-to-day practice: it translates the clause-level descriptions from Chapter 5 and the procedural negotiation tactics from Chapter 6 into a clear entrepreneurial posture toward investors. Instead of treating information rights as an adversarial leverage point, founders are advised to see them as a baseline governance expectation that preserves credibility, simplifies later negotiations, and reduces friction. The practical upshot is both cultural (adopt transparency) and contractual (agree to budgets, financials, and narrowly tailored confidentiality), which together help align economics and control in ways that support growth and investor relationships.

chapter_summaries.summary:
Chapter 8 continues the founder‑centric thread from the prior chapters but narrows the lens to upside and the reality of going public. Building on Chapter 5’s framing of the term sheet as the junction of economics and control and Chapter 6’s procedural negotiation advice, this chapter counsels entrepreneurs to prioritize the elements of a term sheet that materially affect the company’s ability to reach and benefit from an IPO. Rather than spending scarce negotiating capital on registration rights and similar secondary provisions, founders should focus on preserving economic upside and arranging governance mechanics that enable a clean path to the public markets.

Practically, the chapter explains which clauses matter most if an IPO is the desired endgame — liquidation preferences, anti‑dilution mechanics, conversion triggers, board composition, drag‑along and IPO definitions, lock‑ups and secondary sale permissions — and which are relatively low payoff items (notably registration rights). It connects these priorities back to negotiation tactics from Chapter 6 (procedural protections, staged concessions) and the transparency ethic from Chapter 7 (align investors early so IPO timing and mechanics aren’t surprises), giving founders a roadmap to structure term sheets that protect long‑term upside without getting bogged down in less consequential demands.

chapter_summaries.summary: This chapter drills into the restriction on sales—commonly called the right of first refusal (ROFR) on common stock—and its practical place in the term sheet and corporate documents. It explains typical ROFR language, recommends placing the ROFR in the bylaws (rather than scattered in option agreements and plans), and describes the operational mechanics: if the company declines to buy, that right can be assigned to investors. The chapter traces the historical intuition that founders shouldn’t sell before investors could (an idea born when IPOs were faster and secondaries rare), explains how longer liquidity timelines and active secondary markets changed practice, and concludes that an ROFR on common is generally beneficial for the company and founders because it helps manage the shareholder base and keeps transfers visible to the company.

The assignment clause gives VCs operational flexibility to shuffle investments among affiliated funds or managers, but entrepreneurs should ensure any transferee is explicitly bound by the same financing agreements to avoid loopholes. The overall practical lesson: accept these customary provisions, bound them reasonably (time or scope), and focus negotiation energy on provisions with greater founder leverage; when carve‑outs or exceptions are needed (for example, around founders’ activities or IP), expect reciprocal concessions such as different vesting or IP assignments.

The Capitalization Table N. ow that we've worked through all of the specific clauses in the term sheet, let's go through how a typical capitalization table (cap table) works. A term sheet will almost always contain a summary cap table, which we describe in this chapter. You, your prospective investors, or occasionally your lawyers will generate a more detailed cap table. The cap table summarizes who owns what part of the company before and after the financing. This is one area that some founders, especially those who have not been exposed in the past to cap table math, are often uncomfortable with. It's extremely important for founders to understand exactly who owns what part of a company and what the implications are in a potential funding round. Normally when you initially set up the company, 100% will be allocated to the founders and employees, with a specific number of shares allocated to each individual. The question "What will I own if a venture capitalist invests X in my company at a Y valuation?" is rarely simple. To answer it, you need to be able to generate a cap table to truly analyze the deal presented by a particular term sheet. Following is a model to work from with a typical example. Let's assume the following: 2 million shares held by founders before the VC invests $10 million pre-money valuation $5 million investment by the VC In this example, the post-money valuation is $15 million ($10 mil- lion pre-money + $5 million investment). Consequently, the VCs own 33.33% of the company after the financing ($5 million invest- ment/$15 million post-money valuation). This should be pretty straightforward so far. Now, assume the term sheet includes a new employee option pool of 20% on a post-money basis. Remember that this means that after the financing, there will be an unallocated option pool equal to 20% of the company. Although the post-money valuation remains the same ($15 mil- lion), the requirement for a 20% option pool will have a significant impact on the ownership of the founders. Per the cap table, you can see how we calculate the percentage ownership for each class of owner, along with the price per share of the preferred stock. To start, we've filled in the known numbers and now have to solve for the unknowns (A, B, C, D, and E). First, let's solve for A, the founders' ownership percentage: A = 100% minus the VC percentage minus the employee pool percent- age, or 100% - 33.33% - 20% = 46.67%. Given that we know that the 2 million founders' shares represent 46.67% of the company, we can determine that the total shares outstanding (E = 2 million/ 0.4667) are 4,285,408. Now, if there are 4,285,408 shares outstanding, deter- mining the number of shares in the employee pool becomes B = E *0.20 or 857,081. The same math applies for C, the number of shares of preferred stock the VCs have. C = E * 0.3333 or 1,428,326. Since $5 million bought 1,428,326 shares of preferred stock, then the price per share of preferred stock (D = $5 million/1,428,326) is $3.50 per share. Finally, always check your calculation. Since we know we have a $10 million pre-money valuation, then the shares prior to the financ- ing (2 million founders' shares plus the 20% option pool) times the price per share should equal $10 million. chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
Convertible Debt

I,
n the past few chapters we've gone through, in detail, the terms
in a typical venture capital equity financing. However, there is one
other type of financing, often used at the seed stage, called a con-
vertible debt financing. In fact, many angel investors will invest only
with this structure.

Convertible debt is just that: debt. It's a loan. The loan will con-
vert to equity (preferred stock, usually) at such time as another
round is raised. The conversion usually includes some sort of dis-
count on the price to the future round.

For example, assume you raise $500,000 in convertible debt
from angels with a 20% discount to the next round, and six months
later a venture capitalist (VC) offers to lead a Series A round of a
$1 million investment at $1 a share. Your financing will actually be
for $1.5 million total, although the VCs will get 1 million Series A
shares ($1 million at $1 per share) and the angels will get 625,000
Series A shares ($500,000 at $0.80 per share). The discount is appro-
priate, as your early investors want some reward for investing before
the full Series A financing round comes together.

In this chapter, we cover the arguments for and against using
convertible debt. We then go through the terms in a convertible
debt deal, including the discount, valuation caps, interest rate, con-
version mechanics, conversion in a sale of the company, warrants,
and other terms. We briefly cover the differences between early-stage
and late-stage dynamics and finish up with an example of when con-
vertible debt could be dangerous to use.

The chapter then digs into important transactional details: how conversion triggers are written (term length and minimum new‑money amount), amendment and majority‑holder consent risks, the power that outstanding debt can give a noteholder, and the complications that warrants and original issue discount (OID) accounting introduce. Venture Deals is a practical, experience-driven guide that demystifies venture capital term sheets and the financing process for entrepreneurs and new investors. The book opens by mapping the venture ecosystem—who the players are (entrepreneurs, angels, VCs, lawyers, mentors) and how their incentives, time horizons, and constraints shape negotiations. Using historical anecdotes and candid forewords, the authors emphasize that the term sheet is the pivotal negotiating document and reduce its complexity to two core levers: economics (who owns what) and control (who makes the big decisions). From that foundation, the book walks readers clause-by-clause through modern term sheets and explains why particular provisions exist, who asks for them, and how they translate into ownership and governance outcomes.

The middle sections turn the conceptual into the concrete. The authors explain cap-table math with worked examples, show how option pools and post-money vs pre-money mechanics affect dilution, and describe convertible-debt instruments (notes, SAFEs/KISS) and their traps. Interleaved entrepreneur-perspective sidebars provide negotiation strategies: when to fight, when to accept boilerplate, how to handle no-shop clauses, information rights, registration rights, ROFRs, PIIAs, founder activity clauses, indemnification, and assignment. Practical attention is paid to drafting, timing, and the role of counsel—urging founders to understand the math and not blindly trust lawyers.

Later chapters focus on legal hygiene and broader context: the irreversible legal mistakes (83(b) elections, employment/IP documentation) that can destroy value, and the macro view of entrepreneurial ecosystems (the Boulder Thesis) that explains why some places produce sustained startup activity. Throughout, the tone is balanced—sympathetic to founders yet realistic about investor protections—and the book emphasizes transparency, disciplined governance, and relationship-based negotiation. Taken together, Venture Deals mixes legal, financial, strategic, and cultural lessons to make readers able negotiators and better stewards of their companies.

Foreword

remember the first week of my career as a VC. I was 25 years
old, it was 1986, and I had just landed a summer job in a venture
capital firm. I was working for three experienced venture capitalists
in a small firm called Euclid Partners, where I ended up spending
the first 10 years of my VC career. One of those three partners,
Bliss McCrum, peeked his head into my office (I had an office in
Rockefeller Center at age 25) and said to me, "Can you model out
a financing for XYZ Company at a $9 million pre-money, raising
$3 million, with an unissued option pool of 10%?" and then went
back to the big office in the rear he shared with the other founding
partner, Milton Pappas.

I sat at my desk and started thinking about the request. I
understood the "raising $3 million" bit. I thought I could figure
out the "unissued option pool of 10%" bit. But what the hell was
"pre-money"? I had never heard that term. This was almost a decade
before Netscape and Internet search so searching online for it wasn't
an option. After spending ten minutes getting up the courage, I
walked back to that big office, peeked my head in, and said to Bliss,
"Can you explain pre-money to me?"

Thus began my 31-year education in venture capital that is still
going on as I write this.

The venture capital business was a cottage industry back in 1985,
with club deals and a language all of its own. A cynic would say it was
designed this way to be opaque to everyone other than the VCs so that
they would have all the leverage in negotiations with entrepreneurs.
I don't entirely buy that narrative. I think the VC business grew up in
a few small offices in Boston, New York, and San Francisco, and the
dozens-maybe as many as a hundred-of main participants, along

with their lawyers, came up with structures that made sense to them.
They then developed a shorthand so that they could communicate
among themselves.

But whatever the origin story was, the language of venture deals
is foreign to many and remains opaque and confusing to this day.
This works to the advantage of industry insiders and to the disadvan-
tage of those who are new to startups and venture capital.

In the early 2000s, after I wound down my first venture capital
firm, Flatiron Partners, and before we started USV, I started blogging.
One of my goals with my AVC blog (at www.avc.com) was to bring
transparency to this opaque world that I had been inhabiting for
almost 20 years. I was joined in this blogging thing by Brad Feld, a
friend and frequent coinvestor. Club investing has not gone away
and that's a good thing. By reading AVC and Feld Thoughts regu-
larly, an entrepreneur could get up to speed on startups and venture
capital. Brad and I received a tremendous amount of positive feed-
back on our efforts to bring transparency to the venture capital busi-
ness so we kept doing it, and now if you search for something like
"participating preferred" you will find posts written by both me and
Brad on that first search results page.

Brad and his partner Jason Mendelson (a recovering startup law-
yer turned VC) took things a step further and wrote a book called
Venture Deals back in 2011. It has turned into a classic and is now on
its Third Edition. If Venture Deals had been around in 1985, I would
not have had to admit to Bliss that I had no idea what pre-money
meant.

If there is a guidebook to navigating the mysterious and confusing
language of venture capital and venture capital financing structures,
it is Venture Deals. Anyone interested in startups, entrepreneurship,
and angel and venture capital financings should do themselves a
favor and read it.

USV Partner

0
ne of the first famous venture capital investments was Digital
Equipment Corporation (DEC). In 1957, American Research and
Development Corporation (AR&D), one of the first venture capital
firms, invested $70,000 in DEC. When DEC went public in 1968, this
investment was worth over $355 million, or a return of over 5,000
times the invested capital. AR&D's investment in DEC was one of the
original venture capital home runs.

In 1957, the venture capital industry was just being created. At the
time, the investor community in the United States was uninterested
in investing in computer companies, as the last wave of computer-
related startups had performed poorly and even large companies
were having difficulty making money in the computer business. We
can envision the frustration of DEC's cofounders, Ken Olson and
Harlan Anderson, as the investors they talked to rejected them
and their fledgling idea for a business. We can also imagine their
joy when Georges Doriot, the founder of American Research and
Development Corporation, offered to fund them. After a number
of conversations and meetings, Doriot sent Olson and Anderson a
letter expressing his interest in investing, along with his proposed
terms. Today, this document is called the term sheet.

Now, imagine what that term sheet looked like. There are three
different possibilities. The first is that it was a typed one-page let-
ter that said, "We would like to invest $70,000 in your company
and buy 78 percent of it." The next is that it was two pages of legal
terms that basically said, "We would like to invest $70,000 in your
company and buy 78 percent of it." Or it could have been an eight-
page typed document that had all kinds of protective provisions, vesting

<!-- PageNumber="1" -->
<!-- PageFooter="www.itdf.ir" -->
<!-- PageBreak -->

<!-- PageNumber="2" -->
<!-- PageHeader="Venture Deals" -->

arrangements, drag-along rights, and Securities and Exchange Com-
mission (SEC) registration rights.

Our guess is that it was not the third option. Over the past 50
years, the art of the term sheet has evolved and expanded, reaching
its current eight (or so) page literary masterpiece. These eight pages
contain a lot more than "We'd like to invest $X in your company
and get Y% of it," but, as you'll learn, there really are only two key
things that matter in the actual term sheet negotiation-economics
and control.

In DEC's case, by owning 78% of the company, AR&D effec-
tively had control of the company. And the price was clearly
defined-$70,000 bought 78% of the company, resulting in a $90,000
post-money valuation.

Today's venture capital investments have many more nuances.
Individual venture capitalists (VCs) usually end up owning less than
50 percent of the company, so they don't have effective voting con-
trol but often negotiate provisions that give them control over major
decisions by the company. Many companies end up with multiple
venture capitalists who invest in the company at different points in
time, resulting in different ownership percentages, varying rights,
and diverging motivations. Founders don't always stay with the com-
pany through the exit and, in some cases, they end up leaving rela-
tively early in the life of a company for a variety of reasons. Compa-
nies fail, so venture capitalists have gotten much more focused on
protecting themselves for the downside as well as participating in the
upside. Governance issues are always complex, especially when you
have a lot of people sitting around the negotiating table.

While it would be desirable to do venture capital deals with a
simple agreement on price, a handshake, and a short legal agree-
ment, this rarely happens. And while there have been plenty of
attempts to standardize the term sheet over the years, the prolifera-
tion of lawyers, venture capitalists, and entrepreneurs, along with a
steadily increasing number of investments, has prevented this from
happening. Ironically, the actual definitive documents have become
more standard over time. Whether it is the Internet age that has
spread information across the ecosystem or clients growing tired of
paying legal bills, there are more similarities in the documents today
than ever before. As a result, we can lend you our experience in how
venture financings are usually done. The good news is once you've

negotiated the term sheet, you are done with the hard part. As a
result, that's where we are going to focus our energy in this book.

Throughout this book we will cover not only the what and the
how, but also the why things work as they do. Let's begin our explora-
tion of venture capital financings by discussing the various players
involved.

This chapter, “Introduction: The Art of the Term Sheet,” situates the term sheet historically and practically, building on the book’s earlier framing that the term sheet is the negotiating document at the intersection of economics and control. Using the DEC/AR&D anecdote to show how simple early investments once were, the authors trace how term sheets have expanded into multi-page documents packed with protective provisions. They emphasize that despite the proliferation of clauses and lawyers, only two things truly matter in negotiation: economics (who owns what) and control (who steers major decisions). The chapter sets the ground for the rest of the book by explaining that once a term sheet is agreed, the hardest negotiation is typically behind the entrepreneur.

Chapter 6 shifts the book’s focus from describing term sheets and their clauses (Chapter 5) and the players who negotiate them (Chapter 1) to practical, entrepreneur‑centered negotiation tactics. The central, repeated piece of advice is procedural and protective: if a term sheet contains a no‑shop clause — i.e., a provision that prevents the company from soliciting other offers — insist that key employment and founder terms be spelled out before you sign. The chapter flags a VC’s unwillingness to commit to basic employment terms early as a major red flag, because a signed no‑shop can lock founders into a negotiation posture without clear protections on role, compensation, vesting, severance, and change‑of‑control treatment.

The chapter also underscores that term sheets are not absolute guarantees. Beyond the common economic and control provisions discussed earlier, there are many unusual or onerous conditions that can be tucked into a paragraph; if you can imagine it, someone has probably written it. Entrepreneurs are reminded to scrutinize every clause closely, to understand which provisions are binding or condition precedent, and to treat a signed term sheet — especially one with restrictive shop language and unspecified employment terms — as not the same as a closed deal.

Chapter 7, “The Entrepreneur's Perspective,” reframes the term sheet debate around a founder-first norm: embrace transparency with your investors rather than fear it. The author counsels entrepreneurs to adopt the discipline of sending regular budgets and financial statements to shareholders and to view disclosure as part of running a professional, accountable organization; if a founder is unwilling to make that commitment, they should seriously question taking outside investment. For founders who are naturally cautious, the chapter accepts adding a strict confidentiality clause to protect genuinely sensitive information, but treats that as a narrow exception rather than a reason to resist normal investor information rights.

Instead of treating information rights as an adversarial leverage point, founders are advised to see them as a baseline governance expectation that preserves credibility, simplifies later negotiations, and reduces friction. The practical upshot is both cultural (adopt transparency) and contractual (agree to budgets, financials, and narrowly tailored confidentiality), which together help align economics and control in ways that support growth and investor relationships.

Chapter 11 continues the founder‑centric, practical negotiation thread from earlier chapters by focusing on three largely standard-but-important term sheet items: the no‑shop agreement, indemnification, and assignment. Building on the framing of the term sheet as the junction of economics and control (Chapter 5) and the procedural negotiation guidance (Chapter 6), the chapter explains why entrepreneurs should accept and narrowly bound many of these provisions rather than fight over them. The no‑shop clause is presented as a mostly time‑limited, relational commitment (serial monogamy) that helps the lead investor protect the closing process; entrepreneurs should insist on a short, defined period (commonly 30–60 days) and use the clause as a test of the VC’s commitment to close rather than a battlefield for heavy negotiation. Practical anecdotes show that reputation and the character of parties often matter more than strict legal enforcement—acquisition offers or changing economics during a process can and do redirect outcomes without litigation being the central recourse.

The chapter then addresses indemnification and assignment as near‑standard boilerplate: companies are expected to indemnify directors and investors to the fullest extent permitted by law and to procure D&O insurance (often negotiable at Series A but routine thereafter) to attract outside board members. The assignment clause gives VCs operational flexibility to shuffle investments among affiliated funds or managers, but entrepreneurs should ensure any transferee is explicitly bound by the same financing agreements to avoid loopholes. The overall practical lesson: accept these customary provisions, bound them reasonably (time or scope), and focus negotiation energy on provisions with greater founder leverage; when carve‑outs or exceptions are needed (for example, around founders’ activities or IP), expect reciprocal concessions such as different vesting or IP assignments.

The Capitalization Table N. ow that we've worked through all of the specific clauses in the term sheet, let's go through how a typical capitalization table (cap table) works. A term sheet will almost always contain a summary cap table, which we describe in this chapter. You, your prospective investors, or occasionally your lawyers will generate a more detailed cap table. The cap table summarizes who owns what part of the company before and after the financing. This is one area that some founders, especially those who have not been exposed in the past to cap table math, are often uncomfortable with. It's extremely important for founders to understand exactly who owns what part of a company and what the implications are in a potential funding round. Normally when you initially set up the company, 100% will be allocated to the founders and employees, with a specific number of shares allocated to each individual. The question "What will I own if a venture capitalist invests X in my company at a Y valuation?" is rarely simple. To answer it, you need to be able to generate a cap table to truly analyze the deal presented by a particular term sheet. Following is a model to work from with a typical example. Let's assume the following: 2 million shares held by founders before the VC invests $10 million pre-money valuation $5 million investment by the VC In this example, the post-money valuation is $15 million ($10 mil- lion pre-money + $5 million investment). Consequently, the VCs own 33.33% of the company after the financing ($5 million invest- ment/$15 million post-money valuation). This should be pretty straightforward so far. Now, assume the term sheet includes a new employee option pool of 20% on a post-money basis. Remember that this means that after the financing, there will be an unallocated option pool equal to 20% of the company. Although the post-money valuation remains the same ($15 mil- lion), the requirement for a 20% option pool will have a significant impact on the ownership of the founders. Per the cap table, you can see how we calculate the percentage ownership for each class of owner, along with the price per share of the preferred stock. To start, we've filled in the known numbers and now have to solve for the unknowns (A, B, C, D, and E). First, let's solve for A, the founders' ownership percentage: A = 100% minus the VC percentage minus the employee pool percent- age, or 100% - 33.33% - 20% = 46.67%. Given that we know that the 2 million founders' shares represent 46.67% of the company, we can determine that the total shares outstanding (E = 2 million/ 0.4667) are 4,285,408. Now, if there are 4,285,408 shares outstanding, deter- mining the number of shares in the employee pool becomes B = E *0.20 or 857,081. The same math applies for C, the number of shares of preferred stock the VCs have. C = E * 0.3333 or 1,428,326. Since $5 million bought 1,428,326 shares of preferred stock, then the price per share of preferred stock (D = $5 million/1,428,326) is $3.50 per share. Finally, always check your calculation. Since we know we have a $10 million pre-money valuation, then the shares prior to the financ- ing (2 million founders' shares plus the 20% option pool) times the price per share should equal $10 million. While this is close enough for an example, it's not close enough for most VCs, or for most lawyers for that matter. And it shouldn't be close enough for you. That's why most cap tables have two addi- tional significant digits (or fractional shares)-the rounding to the nearest share doesn't happen during intermediate steps but only at the very end. As the entrepreneur, you shouldn't blindly rely on legal counsel to generate these documents. There are a lot of good lawyers out there with poor math skills, and the cap table can get messed up when left in the hands of the lawyers. chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
Convertible Debt

I,
n the past few chapters we've gone through, in detail, the terms
in a typical venture capital equity financing. However, there is one
other type of financing, often used at the seed stage, called a con-
vertible debt financing. In fact, many angel investors will invest only
with this structure.

Convertible debt is just that: debt. It's a loan. The loan will con-
vert to equity (preferred stock, usually) at such time as another
round is raised. The conversion usually includes some sort of dis-
count on the price to the future round.

For example, assume you raise $500,000 in convertible debt
from angels with a 20% discount to the next round, and six months
later a venture capitalist (VC) offers to lead a Series A round of a
$1 million investment at $1 a share. Your financing will actually be
for $1.5 million total, although the VCs will get 1 million Series A
shares ($1 million at $1 per share) and the angels will get 625,000
Series A shares ($500,000 at $0.80 per share). The discount is appro-
priate, as your early investors want some reward for investing before
the full Series A financing round comes together.

In this chapter, we cover the arguments for and against using
convertible debt. We then go through the terms in a convertible
debt deal, including the discount, valuation caps, interest rate, con-
version mechanics, conversion in a sale of the company, warrants,
and other terms. We briefly cover the differences between early-stage
and late-stage dynamics and finish up with an example of when con-
vertible debt could be dangerous to use.

Chapter 13 introduces convertible debt as an alternative to a priced VC equity round, explaining why angels and seed investors often prefer it and how it functions practically as a loan that converts into equity (usually preferred) at the next qualifying equity financing. The chapter gives concrete mechanics (discounts, valuation caps, interest, maturity dates and qualified‑financing thresholds) and shows with examples how discounts and caps determine the effective conversion price. It stresses entrepreneur perspectives — ask for a reasonable financing horizon, forced conversion if the horizon is missed, and prefer a floor (protection for founders) rather than a ceiling on conversion valuation disclosures.

The chapter then digs into important transactional details: how conversion triggers are written (term length and minimum new‑money amount), amendment and majority‑holder consent risks, the power that outstanding debt can give a noteholder, and the complications that warrants and original issue discount (OID) accounting introduce. It contrasts early‑stage (seed/bridge) use with later‑stage bridge financings, and presents the SAFE/KISS synthetic alternatives that remove the debt label (and some edge cases) while bringing their own tradeoffs (no maturity date, fewer investor protections unless added). Practical entrepreneurship advice recurs: avoid double‑dipping (discount plus warrants), be careful disclosing cap terms to prospective VCs, and structure notes thoughtfully to protect founders and align incentives.
